title: SSRF mitigation bypass using DNS Rebind attack

profile.name: Concrete CMS
profile.about: A simple and powerful content management system.

vulnerability_information:
We noticed that the upload functionality contains the ability to upload files from remote server, however there are some mitigations against accessing the AWS Instance Metadata service.

We've managed to bypass these mitigations using DNS rebinding and we've managed to fetch the AWS IAM keys when Concrete CMS is running in the cloud.

We've used http://1u.ms/ service for DNS rebinding, please see screenshots with evidence.

## Impact

An attacker can bypass the SSRF protections and he can fetch the AWS IAM keys under which the application is running. From here on he can do enumeration and mount other attacks.

activities.message:
**This report has been automatically set to "needs more info"** because it does not adhere to the rules listed [on our project page](https://hackerone.com/concrete5). Please go over these rules and resubmit following the directions.

If you've read and complied with all of the rules, please email security@concrete5.org so that this issue may be reopened.

additional_data.old_title: SSRF mitigation bypass to fetch AWS IAM role credentials
additional_data.new_title: SSRF mitigation bypass using DNS Rebind attack

activities.message:
Hi Adrian,
Thanks for this report! It sounds like our main issue is that we are vulnerable to a DNS rebind attack [where we are verifying IP addresses](https://github.com/concrete5/concrete5/blame/develop/concrete/controllers/backend/file.php#L794-L804).
I see a few ways to potentially mitigate this issue, but I'm not sure which would be the most appropriate.

1. Resolve the IP address twice and make sure they are the same. Deny any uploads where two different IPs are detected. I think it'd still be possible for a rebind server to answer with a fake IP multiple times before responding with the real internal IP to get around this
2. Use a specific DNS server to resolve hostnames like opendns (208.67.222.222) which prevents this sort of attack
3. Require HTTPS for provided URLs, I'm not sure that this would be an effective fix since I think you'd still be able to get a valid wildcard certificate that still circumvents our protection.

Thanks again,
Korvin

Hi Korvin,

pleasure. correct, the main issue is that you're vulnerable to DNS rebinding.
1. this sounds good but make sure you dont trigger another DNS query after you checked the ip !     if (ip1 == ip2) { dont_Query_DNS_Again_here(); }
2. it's a domain controlled by the attacker and the attacker's DNS server as well.
3. no

In addition I'd say  to implement a whitelist of allowed hosts to download from. Don't just allow someone to download from any external host, this is dangerous (as shown). Not only the attacker controls the DNS responses but also the HTTPS responses as well.

Hi Korvin,

I've given this more thought, option 2 could work quite well actually, if it's a caching server. The idea is that if that DNS server is queried 2-3 times in short time span (the page generation time) it should always provide the same (first) answer. If the DNS server can provide a different answer for a domain in a short time span then your app is still vulnerable to DNS rebinding.

Thanks,
Adrian
ps: also, no sure why you marked this as  LOW severity, this essentially allows any low privileged user to fetch the AWS IAM credentials. SSRF vulnerabilities are high impact generally speaking.

@adrian_t  Completely understand you asking about the LOW severity. I had exactly the same concern because of the AWS IAM creds being exposed.  We use CVSS v3.1 scoring and when each of the scoring components was analysed and discussed, the score came out as 3.5.  We use the CVSS scoring to take "gut feel" out of the ranking; it prevents knee jerk reactions of "the sky is falling" for a not-so-serious vulnerability as well as escalates vulnerabilities that might have been dismissed. CVSS scoring helps us prioritize based on actual severity. 

Our team ranked the components of this vulnerability as follows:

Vector: Network since it's remotely exploitable

Complexity: High, you need to gain permission to import files and you need to know that the server is on AWS

Privileges: Low, you only need the ability to import a file but you still need dashboard access.

Interaction: None, this attack can be performed by the actor completely without needing any user interaction

Scope: Changed. You are able to access internal IPs but you don't know what those IPs are or what you can access. 

Confidentiality: Low, it's possible to access files on the local network, but there's no way to list them or know what IPs are available without trying them one by one.
The definition for Low confidentiality is:  "There is some loss of confidentiality. Access to some restricted information is obtained, but the attacker does not have control over what information is obtained, or the amount or kind of loss is constrained. The information disclosure does not cause a direct, serious loss to the impacted component."  We scored confidentiality as "low" based on the definition because there is:
1.Not "total loss of confidentiality" 
2.No direct or serious impact is demonstrated here
3.Access to some restricted information is obtained but the attacker does not have control over what information is obtained and the amount or kind of loss is constrained

Integrity: None. The attacker would already need to have permission to upload files so you're just doing allowed stuff from the perspective of "integrity". You can't send POST or PUT requests or anything like that over the network, you can only access unprotected files through GET requests.  The attacker cannot change the files that are already uploaded. The attacker cannot change the AWS IAM settings. Nothing can be modified in AWS. 

Availability: None, you can't effect the availability of the application using this attack.

Note that the scoring above is based on assumption that none of the AWS IAM settings can be changed, just obtained.

Hi @lisaciso ,

we agree with you on most posts when exploiting the SSRF to exploit the local network, however it's a different case when attacking the AWS Metadata instance to get the IAM credentials.
the areas where we differ:

Complexity: Low , as shown dns pinning was easy to pull off, we used a simple existing service designed for this purpose. Also it's easily discoverable that they use AWS, the S3 bucket url gives away this information.

Privileges: Low, we agree here, the user created by the customer was an "editor" as mentioned. 

Confidentiality: This can be high, you never know what IAM credentials (permissions) will get.

Integrity: It's not about changing the IAM settings here. It's about what you can do with the existing AWS role, this can be high.

Availability: same as above.

Anyway,  an ETA for this please?

Thanks.

@adrian_t Thanks for the additional clarification. Your claim that the attacker will actually be able to get and use AWS IAM credentials definitely would escalate the severity.  I will want to talk to our security architect because previously I was informed that nothing could be modified in AWS by exploiting this vulnerability and that an attacker could only gain access to view metadata about the server.

@adrian_t  Hello! We've discussed this as a team. As the Concrete CMS team, we have to rank the discrete Concrete CMS vulnerability. We can't include any AWS (or other cloud service) IMDS misconfiguration or potential IMDS vulnerability into the Concrete CMS ranking.  

Our team's analysis is that it takes a fair amount of misconfiguration to get to a point where IMDS info is dangerous. Our stance is that granting access to servers and locking down credentials are AWS (or other cloud services) configurations and not a vulnerability in the Concrete CMS code base.  

To go into more detail: SSRF vulnerabilities in Concrete (or any other application) can give an attacker access to AWS imds v1 (or equivalent for other cloud providers). Normally that's not a problem since IMDS is just metadata so, under normal circumstances, there's no access if AWS imds v1 is enabled. However, if IMDS was configured to have access to the server it may have some credentials. If those credentials aren't locked down to the network, an attacker could use them to do stuff from the outside. However, as previously mentioned, granting access to servers and locking down credentials are AWS (or other cloud services) configurations and not a Concrete CMS vulnerability. 

AWS and other cloud services have their own vulnerability management programs. AWS, for example, has released imds v2 which specifically patches the SSRF issue. (see https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/defense-in-depth-open-firewalls-reverse-proxies-ssrf-vulnerabilities-ec2-instance-metadata-service/) 

This report is going through PortlandLabs vulnerability management process. We are close to releasing version 9 with a release candidate actively being QA'd by the PortlandLabs team, Marketplace developers, and the Concrete CMS community right now. It is unclear if a fix for this report will be able to make it into that major release or whether it will have to wait for the 8.5.7 and 9.1 release. I will keep you apprised as we know more. 

Right now, a mitigation for this vulnerability would be to make sure that the IMDS configurations for your client are done to AWS (or other cloud provider's) best practices.

Hi @lisaciso ,

there are  a few issues in your post, but I understand where you're coming from.

1) IDMS is not Metatadata!   IMDS always store credentials associated with the AWS IAM role that the application is using. These credentials can have various permissions such as : list S3 buckets/download/upload files, permissions on Ec2 instances or any other types of permissions for any AWS service. 

2) I don't see how IMDSV2 will be a solution here, because I think this is the perfect way to bypass IMSDv2 too. in fact I think I will actually test this, because this seems like the perfect vulnerability to exploit IMDSV2 as well, thanks for the idea ;) 

3) I don't think the client will be happy with this vulnerability in his CMS, but we will see...From personal experience, customers are never happy when an application in their AWS enviroment is vulnerable to SSRF, but it's always good for us as a security company.

Anyway, I will need to know some approximate timelines please for the release of 8.5.7 and 9.1 please. Even some approximation in terms of months for now would be good, even if you don't have more info.

Thanks.

hi @lisaciso ,

I checked this, un indeed IMSV2 stop this, I should have realized this sooner in fact. However I still think that there is an issue with your approach on this bug:

Essentially it's a bug in Concrete CMS, therefore CONCRETE CMS should fix it, you can't rely on the vendor to apply hardening......which they should, but that is a totally different story. From a PR perspective I also think that it would affect Concrete CMS and you'd get the bad press, not the company which didn't to their AWS hardening.

Thanks.

Hi @adrian_t,
This is more a question of severity than a question of whether concrete will allow SSRF requests. This report is still open which means we intend to find a resolution for it.

Hi @korvin ,

thanks, understood.

The severity depends a lot on the permissions attached to the AWS IAM role that the attacker can get once he stolen the AWS keys.  And sometimes that role can can have a lot of permissions, it varies . Depends also on how much Concrete5 CMS has been customised and how many features have been added. More features will require extra AWS IAM permissions -> higher risk.

@adrian_t A fix has been developed and is being merged into the next versions of 9 and 8.5.x  We will be running two versions of Concrete for a bit as the marketplace developers swap over to 9.  I'll keep you apprised. We'll use the same " Adrian Tiron from FORTBRIDGE ( https://www.fortbridge.co.uk/ )" for the credit.

@adrian_t 8.5.7 should be released this week or next. We have obtained CVE-2021-22969 for this vulnerability. As before, we are crediting Adrian Tiron from FORTBRIDGE (https://www.fortbridge.co.uk/ ).  Thanks so very much for all you have done to improve the security of Concrete CMS.   Regards ~ Lisa
